result.execSummary:
This case has not been concluded. Unless a judgment of conviction is entered, the defendant is presumed innocent of all charges.

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.
result.caption: State of Wisconsin vs. David L. Schick

records.descr: Demand for Discovery and Inspection - Defendant

records.addlTxt:
Conditions:
No contact with anyone involved in illegal drug activities, except in a therapeutic setting.
Defendant to maintain absolute sobriety.
Defendant not to consume/possess any alcohol or go into any taverns, bars, liquor stores/place where alcohol primarily is served/sold.
Comply with Pre-Trial Monitoring Services with possible testing based on monitoring level. 
(Covers 22CF1131, 22CF1054)

11:24am Cases called: 22CF1054 & 22CF1131. Defendant David Schick appears in custody via video conference from the Jail with Attorney Ryan Kohler. Prosecuting attorney Matthew Z Kirkpatrick in court for the State of Wisconsin. Waives reading of the complaints. Warrant in 22CF1054 is executed. Time limits for preliminary hearing waived in both files. Bond is set. 
Settlement Conference (by phone) with District Attorney's Office (715-839-4828) on 10/31/22 at 1:30pm
Hearing scheduled for November 23, 2022 at 09:30 am.
